supporting_text: The NAP is a multi-stakeholder plan for the sectors directly impacted by AMR; including human health, animal health, and the environment.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, including improving awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen the animal health sector, including establishing baseline information for AMR in animals.
The NAP addresses environmental health as part of the One Health approach, recognizing the connection between human, animal, and environmental health.
The NAP includes actions related to food safety and the use of antimicrobials in agriculture.
The NAP outlines that progress reports will be compiled by the AMR Secretariat for presentation to the National AMR Steering Committee annually.
The NAP does not specify time-bound targets for tracking progress.
The NAP does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes a cost summary indicating the total cost and funded amounts for the operational plan.
The NAP includes a total cost summary and identifies funded and unfunded amounts for various activities.
The NAP establishes a National AMR Steering Committee for coordinating efforts to address AMR.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen regulations for responsible use of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes strategies to develop educational programs on AMR for schools and health professionals.
The NAP includes actions to conduct awareness campaigns and engage communities in combating AMR.
The NAP mentions collaboration with WHO, FAO, and OIE for AMR initiatives.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen surveillance and laboratory capacity for AMR.
The NAP emphasizes the need for capacity building to detect and report AMR.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention and control across all sectors.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen regulations for the responsible use of antimicrobials.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to promote rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP includes strategies to promote research and development in AMR.
